Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Dictionary Learning for Compressed Sensing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The digital information revolution relies on the sensing and conversion of real-life signals such as speech, music, images and movies to numbers that can be manipulated by computers. Compressed sensing is a recent breakthrough in mathematics that enables to do this sensing and conversion more efficiently and reliably than ever thought possible. Key to this, is the availability of efficient dictionaries that enable very compact representation of natural signals. While dictionaries have been developed from mathematical principles, a recent discovery is that their efficiency can be greatly enhanced, if the dictionary itself is learned from examples of the data. Because compressive sensing depends critically on the interaction of the dictionary with the sensing mechanism, joint learning of the two from the data itself is expected to provide the greatest benefits. However, to date there have been only a handful of heuristic attempts in this direction. The investigator is developing the first
systematic theory for dictionary learning, and for joint learning of dictionaries and sensing mechanism. He will demonstrate the theory and algorithms on real sensing applications, and in particular on challenging medical diagnostic applications.

The specific goals of this project are to develop theory and algorithms with performance guarantees for (i) learning dictionaries for sparse signal representation for compressive sensing; (ii) joint learning of dictionary and the sensing operators optimum for compressive sensing; and to demonstrate the theory and algorithms on challenging magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computerized tomography (CT) applications. Ultimately, this research may lead to MRI and CT techniques for improved imaging of the beating heart or brain function from less data in less time, improving health care and reducing its cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Compressed sensing (CS), first introduced under the name “spectrum-blind sampling”  and “image compression on the fly” in NSF-funded research by the PI in the mid 1990’s, is a technique that enables accurate reconstructions of signals and images from far fewer measurements than the number of unknowns. Following further significant developments and vast popularization in the past decade, compressed sensing has been applied in many areas of science and engineering and to various imaging modalities including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), producing high quality images from few measurements.

The key to the operation of CS, is that the underlying image be sufficiently sparse in some transform domain or dictionary. While CS techniques typically work with fixed dictionaries or sparsifying transforms such as DCT, wavelets, or finite differences, the focus of this project has been instead on blind compressed Sensing (BCS). In BCS, the sparse model for the underlying image or image patches is assumed unknown a priori. Instead, dictionaries or transforms are adapted to or learned from the image or signal that is to be sparsely represented. The goal in BCS is then to recover both the image and the dictionary or transform from only the undersampled imaging measurements. Thus, the BCS problem is harder than conventional compressed sensing. However, it allows the sparse model to be better adaptive to the (unknown) imaged object.

In this project a BCS technique for MRI, dubbed dictionary-learning MRI (DLMRI) was developed, based on learning a so-called synthesis dictionary for sparse signal representation from the data. DLMRI was shown to provide much better image reconstructions for MRI compared to conventional CS methods that utilize only a fixed sparsifying transform or dictionary. First to introduce this approach, this work has since stimulated considerable research along these lines by others.

Departing from the widely popular approach of learning synthesis dictionaries from data, this project introduced a new approach to data-driven adaptation of sparse signal models, called transform learning. It provides improved performance and speed, and much better scaling to large problems. Compared to existing synthesis and analysis dictionary learning methods, the transform learning methods demonstrated improved performance in the classical problems of compact representation and denoising of images, at a fraction of the computational cost. Specific structures for these transforms such as double sparsity, union-of-transforms, square, overcomplete, and filter bank structures, were introduced and investigated.

In addition to batch methods for transform learning, this project introduced online transform learning methods, which are particularly useful and highly efficient for big data or real-time applications. This project demonstrated promising performance for transform learning in sparse representation, in image and video denoising, in image classification, and compressed sensing. In particular, the application of transform learning to BCS in MRI, led to further improvement of image quality even beyond that obtained by DLMRI, and to more than ten fold acceleration of the image reconstruction. This approach was extended to a general formulation for the use of transform learning for BCS, and in addition to MRI, the approach was also successfully applied to iterative tomographic image reconstruction for x-ray dose reduction.

In addition to new approaches and practical and computationally efficient algorithms, this research has established theoretical convergence guarantees for transform learning and image reconstruction schemes that employ them, which were previously lacking for prior adaptive dictionary-based methods.
